name: NPR
text:
The bank accounts of Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny were frozen and his apartment was "seized" in a civil case while he was in a coma after being poisoned with a nerve agent, his spokesperson says.
https://t.co/95sbsECJa0

name: NPR
text:

name: NPR
text: Bernie Sanders: "This is not just an election between Donald Trump and Joe Biden. This is an election between Donald Trump and democracy ‚Äì and democracy must win." https://t.co/4AAV7j0DtS

name: NPR
text:
RT @throughlineNPR: With the death of RBG, the president is hoping to fill the seat with a conservative justice. And evangelicals, who've played an important role in today's politics, have been waiting for this moment.

How evangelicals became such a powerful voting bloc: https://t.co/GFkxNJ5MAe

name: NPR
text:
A white Maryland man has been sentenced to 25 years in prison for shooting a Black man and reportedly telling him to "go back to Africa." Police linked the gunman to white supremacist groups, the prosecutor said.
https://t.co/xJkQ2rN1Y1

name: NPR
text:
Tamika Palmer broke her silence in an Instagram post today.

"It's still Breonna Taylor for me," she wrote beside a portrait of her daughter, followed by a broken-heart emoji and #ThesystemfailedBreonna.
 https://t.co/GlgVCFRzmW

name: NPR
text:
Gov. Andrew Cuomo has signed an order relieving New Yorkers who receive unemployment benefits from having to report part-time income they receive from working for election boards through Nov. 3.
https://t.co/3Q8nIBaLDT

name: NPR
text:
More than half of the people on federal death row are people of color, a new study finds. The victim‚Äôs race also matters a lot, an advocate notes: 

Defendants who kill white people are 17 times more likely to be executed.
 https://t.co/vqeDDhZBUE

name: NPR
text:
The Pac-12 conference has reversed its decision to halt football, voting unanimously to start the 2020 season on Nov. 6, after arriving at a deal with the COVID-19-test maker Quidel.
https://t.co/2uxPSPZMmY

name: NPR
text:
RT @NPRCodeSwitch: On the blog this week, we're diving even deeper our favorite pandemic books. First up, editor @AskLeezul spoke to author @silviamg about the eugenics and colonialism in 'Mexican Gothic' üìö

name: NPR
text: California Gov. Gavin Newsom: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know who the Trump administration is doing bidding for, but they‚Äôre really, really, almost troglodytes in terms of their approach to climate and to the economy and where we‚Äôre going as a nation.‚Äù https://t.co/LKxSKYtnf5

name: NPR
text:
A new report has identified more than 380 suspected detention facilities in China's Xinjiang region, which were built and expanded ‚Äî even as Chinese officials claimed most of the ethnic Uighurs and others sent there had "returned to society."
https://t.co/yyQymzPXi6

name: NPR
text:
When it comes to COVID-19 and pregnancy, an OB-GYN says the virus seems to be able to cross the placenta and infect fetuses ‚Äî but that it "doesn't seem to happen very often."

And, unlike Zika, there isn't evidence of an association with birth defects.
https://t.co/u8KXhpRhKL

name: NPR
text:
Election officials are already reporting a shortage of poll workers for the Nov. 3 election. 

Here's how to sign up.
https://t.co/9nJFyIBBUP

name: NPR
text:
A posthumous memoir by the late Rep. Elijah Cummings is an urgent call to action ‚Äî imploring us to defend our democracy as it is assailed by threats internal and external, writes Ericka Taylor.
https://t.co/rsk8PbwYVK

name: NPR
text: We asked mourners who paid their respects to Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg at the Supreme Court to reflect on the imp‚Ä¶ https://t.co/F0RiTqCMg0

name: NPR
text:
People are getting creative this Halloween. 

"Some of the ideas I've heard are: setting up a chute made of long cardboard tubes or plastic piping, then sending candy down the tubes," a mom says. "Or possibly a clothesline in the yard with candy attached."
https://t.co/H0xCRxv6g4

name: NPR
NPR
text:
In 2017, Matthew was placed in a medically induced coma. Despite having insurance, he wound up having to declare bankruptcy in his 20s. Now he faces another $10,000 medical bill.

"The curse of being sick in America is a lifetime of debt," he says.
https://t.co/73NxKOBA6s

name: NPR
text:
Civil rights groups and Facebook critics are banding together to monitor misinformation, hate speech and voter suppression on the platform because the social network itself, they argue, has fallen short.
https://t.co/fO0OlzJd2u

name: NPR
text: The late Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg is lying in state at the U.S. Capitol today. She is the first woman and first‚Ä¶ https://t.co/jR0fxOXTon

text:
North Korean leader Kim Jong Un said he feels "deeply sorry" for the shooting death of a South Korean fisheries official earlier this week in waters near the two countries' maritime border.
https://t.co/F9zRF8fJj8

name: NPR
text:
The clock is ticking for tens of thousands of pilots, flight attendants, mechanics and other airline employees who will likely lose their jobs on Oct. 1 if Congress doesn't extend federal aid for airlines.
https://t.co/mhdYARFvtO

name: NPR
text:
"I was reassured Wednesday of why I have no faith in the legal system, in the police, in the law," says Tamika Palmer, Breonna Taylor's mother, in a statement.

"They are not made to protect us Black and brown people."

https://t.co/dI3FFJAhZ8

name: NPR
text:
Notably absent from the U.S. Capitol ceremony honoring Ruth Bader Ginsburg on Friday: the two top Republicans in Congress, Mitch McConnell and Kevin McCarthy.

name: NPR
text:

https://t.co/aVdWt8YeaP

name: NPR
text:
A Seattle police officer has been placed on administrative leave pending an investigation after video on social media showed him walking his bicycle over the head of a protester lying on the ground.
https://t.co/cjU6LRdrFq

name: NPR
text:
Sir David Attenborough, 94, joined Instagram this week ‚Äî and promptly broke the world record for the fastest time to reach 1 million followers on the platform.

He did so in just four hours and 44 minutes.
https://t.co/T3NdFsInyz

name: NPR
text:
Federal appeals court judge Barbara Lagoa is high on Trump's list of potential Supreme Court nominees.

She became controversial for not recusing herself from a case on felon voting rights ‚Äî going against judicial ethics rules.
https://t.co/TRrxyDIw92

name: NPR
text:

text:

name: NPR
text: "Before she started, women couldn't buy a house, open a charge card at a department store, without their husband's‚Ä¶ https://t.co/GCms0Xkf2H

text:
This week, Mike Bloomberg raised some $16 million for a Florida fund to help felons pay off fines so they can register to vote.

Now, the Republican state attorney general is calling for an investigation. https://t.co/aNMLFr9JUj

name: NPR
text:
Meet Magawa, a very special rat trained to sniff out explosives. Over the years, he has detected dozens of landmines in Cambodia and is believed to have saved lives.

On Friday, he was honored with a gold medal ‚Äî perfectly rat-sized to fit on his harness.
https://t.co/TphplZI2op

name: NPR
text: RT @nprpolitics: Joe Biden called President Trump's refusal to commit to a peaceful of transfer of power "a typical Trump distraction" and added that he thinks Trump is trying to "take our eye off the ball, not to talk about what's happening to the people dying." https://t.co/W86qNT8q37
